title: My portfolio
description: A meta post about this website.
body:
I built this portfolio site to go into more depth about the projects I've worked on. At the same time, I wanted the process of creating this site to be a learning experience. Rather than grabbing a pre-built Squarespace theme I wanted to get some experience with JAMstack development.

Through the [Syntax Podcast](https://syntax.fm/show/130/the-vuejs-show-scott-teaches-wes) and [following Sarah Drasner](https://twitter.com/sarah_edo) I started to learn about static site generators. The promise of speed and the ease of deploying a static site seemed like a good fit for this site.

I chose Nuxt.JS as it seems to be the standard for JAMstack sites built with Vue. It paired nicely with Netlify as both a headless CMS and way of deploying the site.



This portfolio is my first JAMstack application. It turns out there are a lot of gotchas with Nuxt, so I'm glad I was able to do this project at my own pace.

Check it out on [Github](https://github.com/timmch/my-portfolio).

## Technologies & Libraries
* NuxtJS
* [Tailwind CSS](https://tailwindcss.com/)
** This project was my introduction to Tailwind CSS. I chose it to learn a new method of organizing styles. At first the list of class names in an element seemed crazy and eventually I learned to value Tailwind's approach. It made styling efficient and consistent.
* Vuex
